docs.abstract: In its final season, the HBO satire asks the big questions: Can good coexist with greed? Does money ruin everything — and how much does that matter, if we’re talking billions?
docs.snippet: In its final season, the HBO satire asks the big questions: Can good coexist with greed? Does money ruin everything — and how much does that matter, if we’re talking billions?
docs.lead_paragraph: When “Silicon Valley” premiered on HBO in 2014, Silicon Valley hadn’t yet ruined the world. Those were the salad days for the titans of tech: Digital billionaires were superheroes feted on magazine covers and in the White House, not super villains hauled before Congress for fixing elections, sowing genocide, undermining truth and monopolizing all the globe’s commerce.

headline.main: ‘Silicon Valley,’ Darker Than Ever, Captures the Bleak Mood of Tech

docs.abstract: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
docs.snippet: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple on Monday announced a $2.5 billion plan to address the housing crisis in California, becoming the latest big tech company to devote money to a problem that local lawmakers and economists believe it helped create.

headline.main: Apple Commits $2.5 Billion to Ease California Housing Crunch
headline.print_headline: Apple’s $2.5 Billion Plan For Housing in California

byline.original: By Jack Nicas, Kevin Granville and Conor Dougherty

docs.abstract: Two comedic and poignant favorite series return. A documentary about Mark Rothko debuts.
docs.snippet: Two comedic and poignant favorite series return. A documentary about Mark Rothko debuts.
docs.lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline.main: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

docs.abstract: The New York Police Department, like other law enforcement agencies, has created a podcast that delves into its most interesting cases.
docs.snippet: The New York Police Department, like other law enforcement agencies, has created a podcast that delves into its most interesting cases.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Episode 1 of a new podcast, New York City police officers find the body of an unidentified 4-year-old girl in a cooler near the Henry Hudson Parkway in Upper Manhattan. Technically, she is “Homicide No. 79” of 1991, but the detectives, some of whom have children of their own, rename her: Baby Hope.

headline.main: The Latest Entry in the True-Crime Serial Market: Copcasts
headline.print_headline: For This Crime Show, the N.Y.P.D. Holds the Camera

docs.abstract: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.
docs.snippet: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the beginning of October, my kids’ preschool informed me that it might be closed the next day because of rolling blackouts — a radical new effort by our local power utility in Northern California to avoid sparking wildfires. The water company, faced with the shutdown of its pumps, asked us to fill our bathtubs before the cutoff. On the advice of experts, my car was backed into the driveway for a quick escape, its hatch packed with seven gallons of water and a go-bag including leather gloves, breathing masks, spare clothes, headlamps and emergency food.

docs.abstract: Want to survive the apocalypse? Check out the listings on LuxuryBunkerSwap.com.
docs.snippet: Want to survive the apocalypse? Check out the listings on LuxuryBunkerSwap.com.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Larry Hall touts his condominium’s high ceilings and spacious living rooms. Then there are the swimming pool, saunas and movie theater. But what really sets the development apart, in his view, is its ability to survive the apocalypse.” (The New York Times)

headline.main: Everyone Is Dead, but the Pizza Oven Works

docs.abstract: Are the wealthy addicted to money, competition, or just feeling important? Yes.
docs.snippet: Are the wealthy addicted to money, competition, or just feeling important? Yes.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Billionaires should not exist,” Senator Bernie Sanders said last month. And, at the Democratic presidential debate this week, he said that the wealth disparity in America is “a moral and economic outrage.”

headline.main: Why Don’t Rich People Just Stop Working?

docs.abstract: The body of Tushar Atre, the owner of AtreNet, was discovered hours after he was taken from his California home, the authorities said, and more than one suspect has been identified.
docs.snippet: The body of Tushar Atre, the owner of AtreNet, was discovered hours after he was taken from his California home, the authorities said, and more than one suspect has been identified.
docs.lead_paragraph: The body of a California tech businessman, Tushar Atre, was discovered on Tuesday, just hours after he was kidnapped from his home in Santa Cruz County, Calif., according to the police.

headline.main: Body of Kidnapped Tech Entrepreneur Found, Police Say

docs.abstract: Neither liberal nor conservative, the true ideology of Silicon Valley is an unwavering belief in the power of technology.
docs.snippet: Neither liberal nor conservative, the true ideology of Silicon Valley is an unwavering belief in the power of technology.

docs.abstract: When it comes to non-student accommodations, many college towns offer little more than a weathered chain hotel. These five standouts provide more stylish (and studied) alternatives.
docs.snippet: When it comes to non-student accommodations, many college towns offer little more than a weathered chain hotel. These five standouts provide more stylish (and studied) alternatives.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the real estate developer (and former Starwood Hotels & Resorts executive) Paul McGowan was touring colleges with his daughter, he couldn’t find decent accommodations near the schools they visited. So he launched Study Hotels in 2008, with The Study at Yale. A modernist tower in Philadelphia followed, and two properties — The Study at University of Chicago and The Study at Johns Hopkins — are due in 2021.

headline.main: 5 New Standout Hotels in American College Towns
headline.print_headline: College-Town Digs Much Snazzier Than Dorms
